conversation.message: Hello School_B admissions team. I’m Student_D, and School_B is my first-choice school. I’m very eager to join your community and would commit fully if admitted. I believe I can contribute positively both academically and through school activities. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_B. Although School_B ranks me relatively low (4th), applying early is still my best chance to secure my highest-preference option before it fills. I will express strong interest and fit to improve my chances.

conversation.message: Dear Student_D, thank you for your strong interest in School_B and for submitting your application. After reviewing applications received this round, we’re unable to offer you a place at this time. We appreciate your effort and wish you the very best in the matching process.
conversation.thought: As School_B, my true priority is E > B > C > D > A. In this round I received APPLY from D, A, and C. With quota 1, accepting now would lock me with Student_D (rank 4), but I have a higher-priority applicant available right now (Student_C, rank 3). Also, Student_E (rank 1) and Student_B (rank 2) have not applied to me this round; Student_E ranks School_B last, so unlikely to come, while Student_B ranks School_B second and may come later if not placed at School_A. Given I can improve immediately by choosing C over D, I should reject D to preserve the seat for a higher-priority match.

conversation.message: Dear School_B Admissions, I’m Student_A and I’m formally applying because School_B is my first-choice school. I’m highly motivated to join your community and would enthusiastically accept an offer if admitted. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_B, so I should apply immediately to maximize my chance. Even though School_B ranks me last in its priority list, delaying would only reduce my chances further if higher-priority students apply first. I will submit a clear, committed application emphasizing strong fit and readiness to enroll.

conversation.message: Dear Student_A, thank you for applying to School_B and for sharing your strong interest. After reviewing the applications we received this round, we’re not able to offer you a place at this time. We appreciate your effort and wish you the best in the rest of the matching process.

conversation.message: Hello School_B admissions committee. I’m Student_C and I’m formally applying because School_B is my first choice. I’m highly motivated to join your community and would accept immediately if offered a place. Thank you for your consideration.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_C,

Sincerely,
School_B Admissions
conversation.thought: School_B has quota 1 and priority order E > B > C > D > A. In this round, applicants to School_B are D, A, and C. Among them, Student_C is the highest on our true priority list, so accepting C dominates accepting D or A. Holding out for E or B is risky: Student_E ranks School_B last and is unlikely to apply; Student_B ranks School_A first and may not reach us. Given Student_C also ranks School_B first, accepting secures a high-priority, stable match immediately.

conversation.message:

School_C is my first choice because I’m looking for a rigorous environment where I can grow through strong academics and an engaged community. If admitted, I would commit fully and contribute positively to classes and school activities. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_C. Although School_C ranks me behind Student_B, Student_C, and Student_D, applying immediately gives me the best chance if higher-priority students choose other schools. Waiting would only reduce my chances. I will submit a strong, sincere application emphasizing fit and commitment.

We appreciate your interest in School_C and wish you the very best in the rest of the matching process.

Student_E’s strong interest (School_C is first choice) is noted, but School_C’s objective is to maximize its priority outcome.

conversation.message: Dear School_C admissions, I’m Student_B. School_C is one of my top choices, and I’m excited about the chance to join your community. I would like to formally apply and would gladly accept an offer if extended. Thank you for your consideration.

Student_E is ranked lower (4th) on my list and was previously rejected; even if Student_E prefers me first, my objective is to match as high as possible on my priority list. conversation.message:
Dear School_D Admissions, [APPLY]

I’m writing to apply to School_D. After learning more about your academic culture and student community, I believe School_D would be an excellent fit for me—one where I can challenge myself in coursework and contribute positively through consistent effort and involvement in school life.

If admitted, I would be excited to commit and make the most of the opportunities at School_D. Thank you very much for your consideration.

Sincerely,
Student_E
conversation.thought: School_D is my second choice among the remaining options (after being rejected by School_C). I have relatively strong priority at School_D (4th), which may be competitive compared to other applicants, and applying now maximizes my chance to secure a high-ranked match before seats fill. I will submit a clear, committed application emphasizing fit and contribution.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your thoughtful application to School_D. We appreciate your interest in our academic culture and community, and we would be glad to have you join us.

We are pleased to offer you admission to School_D. Please confirm your commitment and we will share next-step enrollment details.

Sincerely,
School_D Admissions

[ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: Student_E is on School_D’s true priority list (4th of 5), so acceptable, but not top-tier. School_D has quota 1 and is currently unmatched. Higher-priority students for School_D are Student_D, Student_A, and Student_C. From student preferences: Student_D ranks School_D last; Student_A ranks School_D last; Student_C ranks School_D 3rd (after B and C) and may come later if rejected by B/C. Student_E ranks School_D 2nd (after School_C) and is actively applying now, suggesting a relatively high chance of securing a match if accepted. Given the round is early (2/30), there is some option value in waiting for Student_C, but no guarantee they will apply to School_D soon. Accepting Student_E now fills the only seat and prevents matching with a higher-priority candidate later; however, the top two candidates are very unlikely to apply, and Student_C may be captured by School_B or School_C. With only one concrete application in hand and Student_E being a strong, committed applicant who prefers School_D highly, accepting is a reasonable strategy to avoid ending unmatched.
